field_edited_text.value:
'HE NEWS
Vol. XIV. No. 8.
REVIEW OF ATHLETICS
—o—
What This Year Has Meant to
Hopkins
Athletes — Future
Promising.
When most of us came back to "a
dingy little barber shop in the basement" this October we were living
more or less on our nerve as far as
Hopkins athletics were concerned.
We were keeping a siff upper lip, but
the prospects were far from as bright
as we were kidding ourselves into
believing. Last year's football team
had done well, but it was certainly
not a wonder; and with loss of
such g000d men as Capt. Stockett,
"Chance" Bosley," "Ham" Owens,
"Doc" :,Streett, f'Doc" Bryan, and
Alan Chesney, things certainly looked dubious.
The Senior Class is
small and hardly remarkable for
athletic powers.
The sophomores
were largely "black listed."
The
freshmen are an unknown quantity
and the juniors had lost several good
men.
The lacrosse prospects were but
little better, for only five of last
year's team weire back and "Big Bill"
Schmeisser had announced his inability to coach this season. Moreover, Captain Clary, the logical
leader of the team, had been forced
to resign because of his other University work.
Track was indeed the brightest spot
in the athletic future and that was
none too rosy.
Black
"Hooley"
Will be missed in the high jumps,
"Billy" Bond and "Jim" Baily cannot win points in the dashes, "Babe"
Michael will not be able to put the
shot, Russell has graduated, and
"Dutch" Breyer barred by the four
year rule. The loss of these old men
however, only shows how slim were
our best chances in athletics.
But what has happened?
The football team after a pitiful
Opening game that would freeze the
heart out of the most optimistic
black and blue rooter developed into as perfect a football machine as
ever played for Hopkins. Their record speaks for itself:
Md. Agg-ies, 9-0.
Stevens, 6—o.
Randolph-Macon, 8—o.
West. Md., 18-16.
Dickinson, 6-12.
Gallaudet, 38-3.
St. John's, 18-0.
A total of 103 points scored
against our opponents 31; and six
games won (four of them without a
score for the other team) to one
lost.

Baltimore, Md., January 3, 1910.
Lacrosse and track are yet to
come, but our confidence in these
teams is no longer a far-fetched patriotism. We know that they are
going to do as well as the best of
their successful predecessors. There
are bigger and more promising
squads under the tutelage of
Coaches Chesney and Hoffman than
ever before turned out to try for
Both these coaches
these teams.
are masters of their respective arts.
Attractive schedules have been arranged by the respective managements.
Today we are, after a most dismal
outlook, on the threshold of a greater and a more successful athletic future. Hopkins athletics instead of
"going, going, gone" are climbing
up and even higher.
The season is twofold—a closer
bond of interest between the undergraduates and the alumni resulting
in greater spirit and substantial financial backing from the "old boys,"
and increased spirit and a "Heaven
helps those who help themselves"
idea among those of us still in the
University. We owe much to our
alumni and the debt can only be
paid by everyone of us doing all we
can to give them winning teams by
each trying for those teams he is
physically adapted for, or if unable
to do this by morally and vocally
supporting the teams.

ALUMNI NOTES
W. Donnell Stewart, '09, has a position with Sutton, Strother and Co.
Andrew W. Hall, '03, who is now
living in Norfolk, Va., spent the holidays in the city.
Mr. John M. Booker, 'or, who is
teaching at the University of North
Carolina, Chapel Hill, N. C., also
spent the holidays in town.
Dr. A. H. Licklider, who has a position at Dartmouth College, was also in town.
In view of all the talk that is going the round about the substitution
of the English game for our football
it is interesting to note that the fine
play of Donald G. Herring, Princeton, '07, now a Rhodes Scholar at
Oxford was largely responsible for
the victory of his team. This was
the first time that an American has
made the varsity Rugby team of
either of the two largest English
Universities.

ER
Price, 5 cents per copy.

IMPORTANT CONVENTION
ALUMNI PUBLICATIONS
—0—
—0—
Brief Mention of Books Recently Meeting of Philologists and Archaeologists During the HoliPublished by Johns Hopkins
days.
Alumni.
"The real monument to Johns Hopkins is not built of marble or bronze,
but of more permanent stuff, namely
paper. It is the pile of manuscripts,
periodicals and dissertations which,
to quote the words of Dr. Gilman,
is gathered like a bibliothecal cairn in
the office of the trustees to remind
every officer and every visitor of our
productivity in science and letters."
Several additions to this pile have
lately been made. A list follows:
Dr. Walter Clark Haupt, Instructor in German, University of Michigan.
"Die Poetische Form von Goethe's
Faust: Eine Metrische Untersuchung." Leipsig, 1909.
"Das Form Des Urfaust." (Dissertation) Leipsig, 1909.
Dr. Wilfred Pirt Mustard, Collegiate Professor of Latin.
"Later Echoes of the Greek Bucolic Poets." Reprinted from The
American Journal of Philology.
Dr. Frederick M. Warren, Prof.
Modern Languages, Yale,and Lecturer, '09-'io on Old French Literature.
"A Plea for the Study of Medieval
Latin." Reprinted from the "Publications of the Modern Language Association of America."
Clinton Maury Kilby, Ph. D., 1909.
"Redetermination of the Wavelengths of the Arc and the Spark
Lines of Titanium, Mangimese, and
Vanadium; the Effect of Capacity
and Self-induction on the Wavelengths of the Spark Lines."
Reprinted from The Astro-Physical journal (Dissertation).
Dr. Howard E. Enders, instructor
Zool. Purdue University, Lafayette,
Ind. "A Study of the Life History
and Habits of Chaetopterus Variopedatus."
Reprinted from "The Journal of
Morphology." (Dissertation.)
Reid Hunt and R. de M. Taveau,
Bureau of Public Health, Waqiington, D. C., "On the Relation between
the Toxicity and Chemical Constitution of a number of Derivatives of
Choline and Analogous Compounds."
Reprinted from "The Journal of
Experimental
and
Pharmacalog-y
Therapeutics."
Frank Andrews, Scientific Assistant, Division of Production and
Distribution, Bureau of Statistics.
"Cost and Methods of Transporting
Meat Animals."
Continued on page 2, column 2.

During the holidays the meeting
of the Archaeological Institute of
America and the American Philological Association took place at the
University. Many out of town
guests were present, including several of the oldest of the Hopkins Alumni. A unique feature of the convention was the holding of a banquet
at the Belvedere.
There were i8o persons present and
included members of the two associations, men and women, and a few invited guests. The invited guests included Messrs. Theodore Marburg,
Mendes Cohen, Glom Peter Leary,
Jordan Stabler and Miss Julia Rodgers. The guests were seated at
small tables, with the exception of
the large table for the speakers. The
only decorations were candelabra.
Mr. Charles J. Bonaparte acted as
presiding officer and toastmaster.
The speakers were: Prof. Basil L.
Gildersleeve, of Johns Hopkins University Prof. Martin L. D'Ooge, of
Northwestern University of Michigan; Principal, William Peterson,
McGill University, Montreal; Don
Enrique Creel, former Mexican Minister at Washington; Prof. Maurice
Bloomfield, Johns Hopkins University; M. Coromilas, Minister from
Greece at Washington; Mr. Henry
White, former United States Ambassador to France, and Dr. William H.
Ward, New York University.
The election of officers resulted as
follows:
President — Paul Shorey, University of Chicago.
First vice president — John C.
Rolfe, University of Pennsylvania.
Second vice president — Thomas
D. Goodell, Yale University.
Secretary-treasurer—Frank Gardner Moore, Trinity College.
Executive Committee — Frank C.
Babbitt, Trinity College, Hartford,.
Conn.; Albert Granger Harkness,
Brown
University; Clifford
H.
Moore, Harvard University; W. A.
Heide!, Wesleyan University; Wilfred P. Mustard, Johns Hopkins
University.
A gift of $425,000 has recently
been made to Yale for the erection
and equipment of a new physics laboratory. "Such a wicked waste of
good money," was the comment of
one of "Uncle Joe's" Christmas victims.

,THE NEWS-LETTER, January 3., L910.

NUNN 0 COMPANY
BREYER MARRIED
Breyer—Baker
St. John's Protestant Episcopal
Church, Mount Washington, was the
scene of a pretty wedding at 7.30
o'clock Monday evening, when Miss
Marjorie Baker, daughter of Mr.
and Mrs. Henry F. Baker, of Roxbury Place, Mount Washington, became the bride of Mr. Frank G.
Breyer, son of Mrs. F. R. Breyer,
827 Edmondson avenue. The ceremony was performed by Rev. Wilber
F. Watkins, Jr.
The bride wore a white satin and
broadcloth gown, trimmed with pearls
and lace. She had a tulle veil fastened with orange blossoms and
maidenhair ferns and carried lilies
of the valley. Miss Anna Baker,
sister of the bride, was maid of honor
She wore white satin, trimmed with
Irish point lace. Miss Helen Baker
another sister of the bride, was flower girl. She wore white satin and
carried pink roses and white carnations. Mr. Walter Swindell was
best man.
The church was decorated with
Christmas ferns and potted plants.
Miss Bessie Leary, the organist,
played the wedding march. An informal reception followed at the
home of the bride's parents, after
which they left on a honeymoon to
parts unknown to their many friends.
The ushers were Messrs. Albert
Baker, Midshipman Hugh McCullough Branham, C. L. Streett, Evelyth Bridgeman, A. M. Chesney and
H. F. Frank.

'HE NEWS
Vol. XIV. No. 8.
REVIEW OF ATHLETICS
—o—
What This Year Has Meant to
Hopkins
Athletes — Future
Promising.
When most of us came back to "a
dingy little barber shop in the basement" this October we were living
more or less on our nerve as far as
Hopkins athletics were concerned.
We were keeping a siff upper lip, but
the prospects were far from as bright
as we were kidding ourselves into
believing. Last year's football team
had done well, but it was certainly
not a wonder; and with loss of
such g000d men as Capt. Stockett,
"Chance" Bosley," "Ham" Owens,
"Doc" :,Streett, f'Doc" Bryan, and
Alan Chesney, things certainly looked dubious.
The Senior Class is
small and hardly remarkable for
athletic powers.
The sophomores
were largely "black listed."
The
freshmen are an unknown quantity
and the juniors had lost several good
men.
The lacrosse prospects were but
little better, for only five of last
year's team weire back and "Big Bill"
Schmeisser had announced his inability to coach this season. Moreover, Captain Clary, the logical
leader of the team, had been forced
to resign because of his other University work.
Track was indeed the brightest spot
in the athletic future and that was
none too rosy.
Black
"Hooley"
Will be missed in the high jumps,
"Billy" Bond and "Jim" Baily cannot win points in the dashes, "Babe"
Michael will not be able to put the
shot, Russell has graduated, and
"Dutch" Breyer barred by the four
year rule. The loss of these old men
however, only shows how slim were
our best chances in athletics.
But what has happened?
The football team after a pitiful
Opening game that would freeze the
heart out of the most optimistic
black and blue rooter developed into as perfect a football machine as
ever played for Hopkins. Their record speaks for itself:
Md. Agg-ies, 9-0.
Stevens, 6—o.
Randolph-Macon, 8—o.
West. Md., 18-16.
Dickinson, 6-12.
Gallaudet, 38-3.
St. John's, 18-0.
A total of 103 points scored
against our opponents 31; and six
games won (four of them without a
score for the other team) to one
lost.

Baltimore, Md., January 3, 1910.
Lacrosse and track are yet to
come, but our confidence in these
teams is no longer a far-fetched patriotism. We know that they are
going to do as well as the best of
their successful predecessors. There
are bigger and more promising
squads under the tutelage of
Coaches Chesney and Hoffman than
ever before turned out to try for
Both these coaches
these teams.
are masters of their respective arts.
Attractive schedules have been arranged by the respective managements.
Today we are, after a most dismal
outlook, on the threshold of a greater and a more successful athletic future. Hopkins athletics instead of
"going, going, gone" are climbing
up and even higher.
The season is twofold—a closer
bond of interest between the undergraduates and the alumni resulting
in greater spirit and substantial financial backing from the "old boys,"
and increased spirit and a "Heaven
helps those who help themselves"
idea among those of us still in the
University. We owe much to our
alumni and the debt can only be
paid by everyone of us doing all we
can to give them winning teams by
each trying for those teams he is
physically adapted for, or if unable
to do this by morally and vocally
supporting the teams.

ALUMNI NOTES
W. Donnell Stewart, '09, has a position with Sutton, Strother and Co.
Andrew W. Hall, '03, who is now
living in Norfolk, Va., spent the holidays in the city.
Mr. John M. Booker, 'or, who is
teaching at the University of North
Carolina, Chapel Hill, N. C., also
spent the holidays in town.
Dr. A. H. Licklider, who has a position at Dartmouth College, was also in town.
In view of all the talk that is going the round about the substitution
of the English game for our football
it is interesting to note that the fine
play of Donald G. Herring, Princeton, '07, now a Rhodes Scholar at
Oxford was largely responsible for
the victory of his team. This was
the first time that an American has
made the varsity Rugby team of
either of the two largest English
Universities.

Price, 5 cents per copy.

IMPORTANT CONVENTION
ALUMNI PUBLICATIONS
—0—
—0—
Brief Mention of Books Recently Meeting of Philologists and Archaeologists During the HoliPublished by Johns Hopkins
days.
Alumni.
"The real monument to Johns Hopkins is not built of marble or bronze,
but of more permanent stuff, namely
paper. It is the pile of manuscripts,
periodicals and dissertations which,
to quote the words of Dr. Gilman,
is gathered like a bibliothecal cairn in
the office of the trustees to remind
every officer and every visitor of our
productivity in science and letters."
Several additions to this pile have
lately been made. A list follows:
Dr. Walter Clark Haupt, Instructor in German, University of Michigan.
"Die Poetische Form von Goethe's
Faust: Eine Metrische Untersuchung." Leipsig, 1909.
"Das Form Des Urfaust." (Dissertation) Leipsig, 1909.
Dr. Wilfred Pirt Mustard, Collegiate Professor of Latin.
"Later Echoes of the Greek Bucolic Poets." Reprinted from The
American Journal of Philology.
Dr. Frederick M. Warren, Prof.
Modern Languages, Yale,and Lecturer, '09-'io on Old French Literature.
"A Plea for the Study of Medieval
Latin." Reprinted from the "Publications of the Modern Language Association of America."
Clinton Maury Kilby, Ph. D., 1909.
"Redetermination of the Wavelengths of the Arc and the Spark
Lines of Titanium, Mangimese, and
Vanadium; the Effect of Capacity
and Self-induction on the Wavelengths of the Spark Lines."
Reprinted from The Astro-Physical journal (Dissertation).
Dr. Howard E. Enders, instructor
Zool. Purdue University, Lafayette,
Ind. "A Study of the Life History
and Habits of Chaetopterus Variopedatus."
Reprinted from "The Journal of
Morphology." (Dissertation.)
Reid Hunt and R. de M. Taveau,
Bureau of Public Health, Waqiington, D. C., "On the Relation between
the Toxicity and Chemical Constitution of a number of Derivatives of
Choline and Analogous Compounds."
Reprinted from "The Journal of
Experimental
and
Pharmacalog-y
Therapeutics."
Frank Andrews, Scientific Assistant, Division of Production and
Distribution, Bureau of Statistics.
"Cost and Methods of Transporting
Meat Animals."
Continued on page 2, column 2.

During the holidays the meeting
of the Archaeological Institute of
America and the American Philological Association took place at the
University. Many out of town
guests were present, including several of the oldest of the Hopkins Alumni. A unique feature of the convention was the holding of a banquet
at the Belvedere.
There were i8o persons present and
included members of the two associations, men and women, and a few invited guests. The invited guests included Messrs. Theodore Marburg,
Mendes Cohen, Glom Peter Leary,
Jordan Stabler and Miss Julia Rodgers. The guests were seated at
small tables, with the exception of
the large table for the speakers. The
only decorations were candelabra.
Mr. Charles J. Bonaparte acted as
presiding officer and toastmaster.
The speakers were: Prof. Basil L.
Gildersleeve, of Johns Hopkins University Prof. Martin L. D'Ooge, of
Northwestern University of Michigan; Principal, William Peterson,
McGill University, Montreal; Don
Enrique Creel, former Mexican Minister at Washington; Prof. Maurice
Bloomfield, Johns Hopkins University; M. Coromilas, Minister from
Greece at Washington; Mr. Henry
White, former United States Ambassador to France, and Dr. William H.
Ward, New York University.
The election of officers resulted as
follows:
President — Paul Shorey, University of Chicago.
First vice president — John C.
Rolfe, University of Pennsylvania.
Second vice president — Thomas
D. Goodell, Yale University.
Secretary-treasurer—Frank Gardner Moore, Trinity College.
Executive Committee — Frank C.
Babbitt, Trinity College, Hartford,.
Conn.; Albert Granger Harkness,
Brown
University; Clifford
H.
Moore, Harvard University; W. A.
Heide!, Wesleyan University; Wilfred P. Mustard, Johns Hopkins
University.
A gift of $425,000 has recently
been made to Yale for the erection
and equipment of a new physics laboratory. "Such a wicked waste of
good money," was the comment of
one of "Uncle Joe's" Christmas victims.

,THE NEWS-LETTER, January 3., L910.

NUNN 0 COMPANY
BREYER MARRIED
Breyer—Baker
St. John's Protestant Episcopal
Church, Mount Washington, was the
scene of a pretty wedding at 7.30
o'clock Monday evening, when Miss
Marjorie Baker, daughter of Mr.
and Mrs. Henry F. Baker, of Roxbury Place, Mount Washington, became the bride of Mr. Frank G.
Breyer, son of Mrs. F. R. Breyer,
827 Edmondson avenue. The ceremony was performed by Rev. Wilber
F. Watkins, Jr.
The bride wore a white satin and
broadcloth gown, trimmed with pearls
and lace. She had a tulle veil fastened with orange blossoms and
maidenhair ferns and carried lilies
of the valley. Miss Anna Baker,
sister of the bride, was maid of honor
She wore white satin, trimmed with
Irish point lace. Miss Helen Baker
another sister of the bride, was flower girl. She wore white satin and
carried pink roses and white carnations. Mr. Walter Swindell was
best man.
The church was decorated with
Christmas ferns and potted plants.
Miss Bessie Leary, the organist,
played the wedding march. An informal reception followed at the
home of the bride's parents, after
which they left on a honeymoon to
parts unknown to their many friends.
The ushers were Messrs. Albert
Baker, Midshipman Hugh McCullough Branham, C. L. Streett, Evelyth Bridgeman, A. M. Chesney and
H. F. Frank.
